snippet: Tying Egypt’s debt forgiveness to the country’s efforts to protect American interests there and shaping a post-Qaddafi Libya were among the specific positions Mitt Romney’s advisers said he would take.
abstract: Senior foreign policy advisers for Mitt Romney provide a detailed narrative of how Romney would have handled a streak of recent crises in the Middle East, offering a specificity far greater than what Romney himself has offered on the campaign trail, where he speaks in board strokes about his foreign policy plans.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and ASHLEY PARKER
byline.contributor: David E. Sanger reported from Washington, and Ashley Parker from Fairfax, Va.

lead_paragraph: Tying Egypt’s debt forgiveness to the country’s efforts to protect American interests there and shaping a post-Qaddafi Libya were among the specific positions Mitt Romney’s advisers said he would take.

headline.seo: Romney Aides Detail Foreign Policy Differences
headline.main: Amid Mideast Turmoil, Aides Say What a President Romney Would Do
headline.print_headline: Amid Mideast Turmoil, Aides Say What a President Romney Would Do

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
keywords.name: subject
